beats.label: HOOK + PROMISE
beats.narration: Should you race Trans-Sylvania Epic? I rated 328 gravel races on 14 dimensions. Trans-Sylvania Epic scored 51 out of 100. Solid tier. Here's what that actually means for your season.
beats.editing_note: STATE THE PREMISE IN 8 SECONDS. Clear value prop: 'I rated 328 races. Here's where this one lands.' This is the 8-second decision window. Viewers who stay past 15s are 58% more likely to finish.
beats.psych_mechanism: Curiosity gap (specific) + IKEA effect (viewer predicts the tier before reveal).

beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Trans-Sylvania Epic. Pennsylvania. 225 mi. PA mountain multi-stage gravel.
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: The numbers. All fourteen of them. Length. 4 out of 5. This is a long day. Plan accordingly. Sam Koerber explains "The courses are generally shy of three hours for the leaders and as a result the pace is relentless. Logistics. 3 out of 5. Gets the job done. Nothing fancy. Seven Mountains Scout Camp provides the central base with mandatory Stage 0 registration keeping everyone oriented. Technicality. 3 out of 5. Technical enough to thin the pack. Pennsylvania forests typically serve up rocky, rooty terrain with sustained climbs rather than explosive technical features. Elevation. 3 out of 5. The hills sort the trained from the untrained. The 15,000 feet over 225 miles creates what Mical Dyck calls "constant false flats so you have to pedal through smaller rocks all day. Climate. 3 out of 5. The weather could go either way. Historical weather data shows average highs of 71°F and lows of 49°F, with a 49% chance of rain on any given day. Adventure. 3 out of 5. Genuine adventure elements. Expect the unexpected. Multi-day stage racing through Pennsylvania's forest systems with evocative names like Poe Paddy and Coopers Gap delivers backcountry exploration. Experience. 3 out of 5. You'll remember this one. Mostly fondly. Multi-day stage racing through Pennsylvania's Rothrock and Bald Eagle forests with named stages like Poe Paddy and Coopers Gap has potential for solid adventure. Community. 3 out of 5. Community is a real selling point. The "Singletrack Summer Camp" nickname captures the social atmosphere where riders call truces and "just rode bikes and cheered on our fellow tryers.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: The rest. Quick-fire. Prestige. 2 out of 5. Known in certain circles. Niche following. Race Quality. 2 out of 5. Basic but functional. Gets the job done. Field Depth. 2 out of 5. Enough competition to keep you honest. Value. 2 out of 5. Not the worst deal. Close though. Expenses. 2 out of 5. Not cheap. The costs pile on. Altitude. 1 out of 5. Low altitude. Breathe easy.
